reviews.review_msg: Worst elective you can take, consider something else if you can.

Wouldn't recommend this elective with Scott Harrison. Doesn't give enough time on exams like the final, 30 mins for 40 MCQs and 30 mins for 3 essays needing huge detail. TAs mark very harshly. Lectures/slides are long, unclear, and unhelpful. Barely responds to emails, replies curtly. Avoid this prof, not the kind of easy elective you'll expect.

Be prepared to write the midterm + final in an hour. The written portion for the midterm and the final is super extensive and asks for way too much detail for only 30 minutes given. You're allowed to have a cheat sheet for the written , but you'll barely use it as most of the questions involve topics that weren't covered in depth. Not a GPA booster

Got the midterm in 2 days and its on zoom smh thats not even the issue 21 mcq in 15 min and then 3 essay questions in 30 min wtf is this does this mf want us to not even finish the exam. I took ts as an elective since I was actually intrested in the topic but his lecture slides and videos are awful. And his exams are too much.

The slides have limited text, but his wordy explanations pushes students to make their own connections to grasp concepts; the outdated videos should be simplified to consider the students' learning. I later realized he didn't make the slides, explaining the disconnect and lack of cohesion. Lectures felt demotivating, and a drag to follow.
don't take. not a real gpa booster lol. bad ta's

final was 40mcq in 30 mins and 3 written questions with 8 part each in another 30 mins. take him if you actually memorize and know all your stuff because you won't have enough time during exams to finish your writing. lectures start off easy but then eventually you'll have 5 40min videos a week.
He is witty and helpful

The course itself was difficult, but useful
Scott makes lectures funny and engaged, very easy to follow. 
Learned valuable things from this course and I would recommend.

Took 3 courses with Scott. Probably my favourite prof in REM. He'll definitely challenge you but getting an A is very attainable. He cares about students and will spend time getting to know you and explaining concepts. Very funny, shares stories from his early career. Motivating as well.

Scott is one of the best profs I have had. He is a stickler for the rules but as long as you follow the very clear assignment guidelines you will be fine. His exams are a beast but once you know how he writes them they are fairly average.
Only thing i would change is the confused powerpoints, other then that very interesting classes
hard but good teacher
one of my fav profs
nice guy

Scott is a great teacher, my favorite in REM. Really engaging lectures and he is very helpful and puts you on the spot to better teach you the concepts. He is accessible outside of class and wants you to succeed. The exams for this course are really tough. Even though I would study for weeks before the tests, I've never gotten the mark I would like

The lab work for REM 311 is decent (this is where you should make up most of your grade) and his lectures are okay. But his tests are beyond hard. They are made to be extremely hard and tricky. It really says something when the class average on his tests are less than about 55% and no curve. Good luck in his class!

Though Prof. Harrison's REM 311 was informative, the overwhelming workload, harsh grading, and an unreasonable stance on academic dishonesty marred the experience. Inconsistent evaluations and trick exam questions felt unjust. Approach with caution. I gave him a chance considering the reviews, but I was WRONG to do so. PLEASE AVOID!

Scott is an okay teacher. His lecture videos were long and he has a monotone voice which makes it harder for me to stay focus. He doesn't have a clear criteria on the assignments. I had to keep emailing him about it which is annoying. The TAs who marks them are tough graders

This is the third course I'm taking with Scott. I would take more courses with him if I could. Scott is very caring, funny, and fair. Scott's passion for ecology and wildlife is capturing and his lectures are inspirational. Scott is available outside of class and very responsive to emails. Best prof in the REM department!
His lectures are great but he grades poorly

Awesome prof and class! Content was inspiring, projects and grading were fair, and Scott is very passionate, knowledgeable, and funny, and is always available to talk after lecture. Only complaint is the time constraints/format of the midterm/final which made it a bit harder to show what you know. Hope to take a class w/ Scott again!

I agree with the latest person who mentioned that he is strict with academic integrity. Ive taken other classes with him and his exams are the worst and are made to trick you. You cant go back to previous questions and the wording is confusing. He never answers questions but he is a nice guy. But not the best teacher.
Very helpful teacher when taking his class for technical writing REM202w. He takes feedback well for his lectures and changes slides up and gives good feedback when needed and asked.

He provided great information and made the lectures very interesting. He does talk extremely slow, but online allowed me to listen to him on 2x speed which worked out very well. His exams and assignments are also fair, although watch out for trick questions on his multiple choice.

Professor Harrison made me understand climate change and the importance of REM more. However, in his lectures he speaks super slow so I'd recommend changing the speed of his pre-recorded lectures. He's a nice professor and approachable outside of class.

Great professor, very organized and passionate about the subject. Understood everything by heart and learned a lot from this class. Professor teaches like he's telling a story. Would definitely recommend it.

Scott Harrison is a extremely slow speaker and makes the material seem more boring than in reality. The course itself is cool and it furthers your knowledge of the environmental management around the world that contributes to climate change. The material is super easy, yet take a different prof if you can!
Very fair and friendly prof! Overall, assignments and tests are reasonably fair. There are some group projects and a paper but are easily doable with the right mindset and hard work.

His lecture videos are alright. But him and the TA's don't answer any emails, nor do they give any guidance for this course. Supposed to do a group project but they can't even tell you who your group is or how to contact them.

One of the worst courses Ive taken. Assignments didnt follow from lecture content at all and half of the exams were trick questions. Scott was unhelpful and wouldnt clarify things. Everyone did bad on the midterm and he wouldnt let you see your own exam to improve for the final. Very frustrating experience for a course that shouldnt be hard.

Scott is patronizing and has no interest in student success  the course seemed designed for us to do poorly. His communication was poor and he only answered emails 1 hour/week. Expectations unclear and constantly shifting. Assignments are long and confusing. Exams are full of errors and exam procedures are restrictive and unnecessarily stressful.

I've taken 3 classes with Scott now, and I would take more if I could. This class was really tough and I really had to work for my grade, but it was so rewarding. Scott is really helpful and concerned about students doing well. He makes classes entertaining with his nerdy humour and stories about personal experiences in the field of ecology. A++

When our class transitioned into online halfway through the semester he became a little unorganized. The class is harder than I thought for what was supposed to be an easy elective. Scott himself seems like a really cool person who is passionate about what he teaches, but he often forgets REM is a 100 level course. Makes tests hard too.

This class is my fav so far at sfu, it covers the foundation of resource and environmental mgmt. Very insightful and very much relevant in the world today. His lectures are very easy to understand. Assignments and tests are not hard at all. Wholesome prof 10/10 would take classes by him again!

I found this prof to be a little difficult... Because he works for the government, I felt like he had a preconceived notion and a very specific mindset on what ecology and conservation is, and how natural resources should be managed. I would recommend taking his courses in senior years; his teaching and writing is very advanced for undergraduates.

Prof. Harrison is a great lecturer. I am taking REM100 as an elective this semester and it is turning out to be an amazing class because of him. He inspires us (or at least me) to be smarter and more conscious about my effect on the environment. He provides a well rounded view that shows minimal bias towards one point of view or the other

Great prof, hard class. Go to lectures so you can understand how to work through his slides. He is very descriptive in his lectures but not in the slides. Midterm/final were tough.. lot's of material covered with very specific answers.

Entertaining lectures because he incorporates real world stories and changes things up frequently. Scared me at first with emphasis on how much work the class would be, and while it was assignment heavy, it ended up more manageable than I thought. No instruction in labs, which was tough, and you actually do need the textbook despite what he says.

Generally, people like him. My friends who took REM 311 with him last semester really enjoyed having him as a prof because he tells cool stories about the field work he's done around the world. He works with the government during the week and only comes to campus on Fridays, but offered his whole day to our class (other than when he's teaching fore
